fields.htmlBody:
Course Overview

Welcome to DataExpert, and congratulations on the start of your journey to becoming a data expert! This introductory course will cover the basics of the Python programming language. No prior programming experience is required, as we will teach you all that you need to know to become a competent Python programmer, with a specific focus on data science use cases. Not only is Python one of the most popular programming language amongst data experts (Data Analysts, Data Scientists, Data Engineers), it is one of the most popular programming languages out there! In fact, according to GitHub's 2019 annual developer survey, known as Octoverse, "Python outranked Java as the second most popular language on GitHub by repository contributors."

If this is your first foray into the world of computer programming, learning Python is an excellent programming language to begin with because it is a general-purpose, high-level programming language. In short, Python can be used to accomplish a wide array of distinct tasks (general-purpose), and it is fairly straightforward to understand and write Python code, as the language implementation abstracts a lot of the complexities associated with how the code is actually executed (high-level). This allows you to easily write code that will do what you want in a simple and understandable manner.

Each one of our lessons is structured in a way that will allow you to:

  • learn new concepts
  • build upon previous concepts
  • apply your newfound knowledge via interactive coding challenges and guided projects
A single lesson within a course is composed of multiple slides. The majority of slides will contain a text editor for you to write your code, buttons for you to be able to execute your code and check whether or not you completed the coding challenge correctly, and an output area that will display the results of your code being executed. This way you will stay engaged, interested, and be able to retain as much information as possible. The course material is dense, yet succinct, and we try to break down complex topics into simple and understandable chunks. The difficulty of the material will increase steadily, giving you the opportunity to slowly accumulate the skill-set and knowledge necessary to complete our guided projects and eventually get a job!

Throughout our lessons you will see that certain words and phrases link to an article or documentation online, which will provide a more in depth explanation of that topic. We highly suggest that you dedicate some time to do this extra reading, as it will help you gain a better understanding of the whys and hows. If we come across an article that does a great job of explaining an important topic and/or goes into greater depth on it than we do, we will link you to it. In addition, everything Python related is documented online, and being able to understand this documentation is an indispensable skill that will go a long way. If the documentation seems intimidating and overwhelming at first, do not feel discouraged. As you gain more knowledge and experience while going through our lessons, you will slowly gain the ability to decipher more complex technical information, such as programming documentation. Remember, Rome was not built in a day, and you will not become a data expert in a day. With hard work, dedication, and persistence, everything will come together and you will prevail. Please be patient, stay excited, and get ready to become a true DataExpert! Now, let's get started.

Arithmetic Operations

We write code in a programming language to instruct the computer to perform a single, or series, of tasks for us. The most basic of these tasks are arithmetic operations - addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and exponentiation. To perform these calculations, we have to let the computer know (by giving it commands):

  • which numbers to perform the calculation(s) on
  • which calculation(s) to perform

For the second bullet point above, we make use of Python’s arithmetic operators, which perform calculations on two or more numbers, known as operands. Before we continue, we want to point out that any text within a slide with a light gray background, such as print('hello world'), is Python code. Now back to arithmetic operators:

  • Addition Operator: +
    • 6 + 2
  • Subtraction Operator: -
    • 6 - 2
  • Multiplication Operator: *
    • 6 * 2
  • Division Operator: /
    • 6 / 2
  • Exponentiation Operator: **
    • 6 ** 2 , which is 6 to the power of 2, or 36.

In addition to the five basic arithmetic operators above, Python supports two other, less commonly known arithmetic operators:

  • Floor Division Operator: //
    • This operator returns the maximum number of times that one number, lets call it x, can be evenly divided by another number, y. When we say evenly, we mean without anything left over.
      • 10 // 2 would return 5, as 10 can be evenly divided by 2 only 5 times: 10 = 2 x 5
      • 10 // 3 would return 3, as 10 can be evenly divided by 3 a maximum of 3 times, and there would be a remainder of 1: 10 = (3 x 3) + 1
      • 5 // 10 would return 0. This is a tricky one, but the reasoning is that 5 cannot be evenly divided by 10 any number of times. Another way to put is that there is no integer greater than 0 for which 10 times that integer would get you a value less than or equal to 5. So for the floor division operator, if the number to the right is greater than the number to the left, the result will always be 0.
  • Modulus Operator: %
    • In contrast to the floor division operator, this operator returns the remainder after attempting to divide one number, x, by another number, y. Although, if x is less than y, then the result would just be x itself.
      • 10 % 2 would return 0 since there is no remainder when dividing 10 by 2.
      • 10 % 3 would return 1, as there is a remainder of 1 when dividing 10 by 3.
      • 5 % 10 would return 5 because 5 is less than 10.

The rules above for the floor division and modulus operators will always hold when both operands are positive. Things get weird when you start using negative numbers, and we highly doubt that you will ever have to use negative numbers with these two operators.

For arithmetic operations, the operands can be:

  • Integers - whole numbers without a decimal point
    • 50, 2, -100, 5, 234
  • Floating Point Numbers (aka Floats) - numbers with a decimal point
    • 1.452, 3.14, 0.75653, 123.7

There are also special cases where we can use arithmetic operators with non-numeric data, and you will learn about this later on in the course. Lastly, we can make use of multiple arithmetic operators on a combination of integers and floats, and in a single command:

  • 5.7 * 10 - 2.5 + 3
  • 5 ** 2 / 5 + 40.8

Coding Challenge

When writing out a single, or sequence, of Python commands (also known as source code) to be executed, we usually do so in a source code editor. As you have probably already noticed, there is a source code editor on the top right hand side of the screen. This is where you will write all of your code while going through the lessons.

Right below the source code editor, there is a row of buttons that you will be using quite frequently:

  • Execute Code - this button will execute all of the code that you have written in the source code editor, and then display the results on the bottom right hand portion of your screen.
  • Submit Answer - this button will do the same as the Execute Code button, but will also check to see if you answered the coding challenge question(s) correctly.
  • Restore Code - this is the circular, light green button to the right of the Submit Answer button. If you click it and then click Restore Code in the pop-up box that will appear, any code that you wrote and is currently in the source code editor for the slide that you are on will be replaced with the default code for that slide. The default code for a slide is either no code at all, or preset code that we create, which you will see on the screen the first time you come to a slide.

For this coding challenge, please enter the following command in the source code editor, and then press the Submit Answer button:

  • print(20 * 3 + 150)

Congratulations on writing your first line of code!

Print Function

For the previous slide's coding challenge, the command that you had to execute was print(20 * 3 + 150). This command utilized Python’s built-in print() function (we will explore functions in great depth later on). What happened behind the scenes when you executed print(20 * 3 + 150)?

  1. Python first performed the calculations within the parenthesis, 20 * 3 + 150. The order of operations in Python is determined by PEMDAS:
    • First, 20 was multiplied by 3 to get 60.
    • Then, 150 was added that product of 60 to get the final value of 210.
  2. print(210) was executed, which instructs Python to display the value that is within the parenthesis of print(210) on your screen.

If you had just entered 20 * 3 + 150 into the text editor without using the print() function, Python would still perform the calculations behind the scenes, but result would not be displayed on the screen. That is why we use the print() function.

Every distinct command in your source code must be separated by a new line. For example, if you want to use the print function more than once:


As you can see above:

  • There are multiple, distinct arithmetic expressions, and each one is contained in a separate print() function.
  • Each time the print() function is used, it is on a new line in the source code editor. Please note that it does not matter if the next print() function is on the line directly below the current one, or five lines down, as long as it is on a new line.
  • The output of executing the source code displays the resulting value of each expression in the same order as the commands are written in the source code. Python executes your source code from top to bottom.

If there are multiple print() functions on the same line in the source code, Python will display the following error message when we try to execute the code:


The great thing about Python is that it always tries to give us enough information to be able to dissect the issue(s) in our code. Here it is telling us:

  • Which line in the source code is causing the error - line 1
  • The type of error - SyntaxError
  • A brief description of the error - invalid syntax

Syntax is the next topic that we will explore.

Coding Challenge

For this challenge, your task is to create source code that will evaluate and display the results of the following distinct arithmetic expressions on the screen:

  • (5 * 4.5) + 15
  • 10 / 3
  • 3 - 274.7 + 54

Python Syntax

Any natural language, such as English, has certain grammar rules that you must follow in order to construct valid sentences. This is also the case for all programming languages. Each unique programming language is analogous to a human language, and requires adherence to specific grammar, also known as syntax, rules. These syntax rules define whether or not your code is properly written, and if it is not, you will most definitely get a SyntaxError when trying to execute the code. Some of Python's syntax rules that you have already come across (explicitly and implicitly) are that:

  • Every distinct command must be separated by a new line in your source code.
    • In the previous slide, we showed you the output (SyntaxError) of trying to execute code that had two consecutive print() functions separated by a space instead of a new line.
  • To properly utilize a function within your source code, it must be written in the following format: name_of_function(function arguments).
    • Lets use print(5 + 5) as an example. The function's name is print, followed by an open parenthesis (, the arguments passed to the function (which we will cover in a later lesson) 5 + 5, and finally a close parenthesis ). What would happen if we used a close square bracket instead of parenthesis?

As you can see, Python throws a SyntaxError. Now, what if we accidentally used a symbol that is not a valid arithmetic operator?


Another SyntaxError, as you might have expected. In both of the examples above, Python tried pointing us to the exact location of the syntax error in our source code.

To avoid syntax errors, you must be diligent when writing code. We have just covered a few of Python's various syntax rules, but will continue to highlight proper Python syntax as new concepts are introduced. Similar to speaking and writing in a natural language, as you become a more experienced coder, writing syntactically accurate code gets easier. And for the times when there are syntax errors in your source code, Python will throw a SyntaxError, and try to point you to where the error occurred.

As you gain more experience writing code, the length and/or complexity of your code will increase. In addition, code you write will potentially be looked at, used, or edited by either you or someone else. This is where comments come in handy, as they allow you to explain what a certain portion of code is doing.

We make use of comments in Python with the hashtag symbol #. As you already know, the interpreter executes your code line by line. During execution, it ignores any text that comes after a hashtag, which tells it "I am a comment, ignore me!"

Comments can be placed:

  • on their own line within the text editor
  • after a legit command

Some things to note about using comments in your code:

  • If you start a new line with a comment and then on that same line continue writing legitimate Python code, the interpreter will not execute the code. It will consider it as being part of that comment. For example, the interpreter will interpret the following line as a comment:
    • # this is a comment print(5 / 5)
  • When placing a comment after a command on the same line, it's best practice to add a space or two in between the end of the command and the start of the comment:
    • print(5 / 5) # this is a comment

How often should you include comments in your code? There is no set amount, but our suggestion would be to include them only when you deem necessary. Although, there is such a thing as too many comments. You don't want to include them for code that can be easily understood by a competent programmer.

We'll occasionally make use of comments in the default code for certain slides, and our guided projects solution code. If you'd like, you can use these as a guide for including comments in your own code.

Feel free to experiment with the print() function and Python comments in the text editor. There is no coding challenge for this slide.

Congratulations on completing your first DataExpert lesson!

Every lesson concludes with a summary slide that:

  • Highlights and briefly summarizes key concepts from the lesson.
  • Has links to articles and/or documentation for new terms introduced throughout the lesson that we believe would be worthwhile for you to look into.

Key Concepts

  • Python is one of the most, if not the most, widely used programming languages in the data science world. This is due to its versatility, ease of use, and continued support for data science use cases (we will go into more detail on the last reason later on).
  • Humans utilize programming languages to instruct the computer to perform specific commands, the most basic being arithmetic calculations.
    • To perform arithmetic calculations in Python, you need to use its arithmetic operators: + - * / **.
  • The print() function can be used to display numbers (integers, floats), or the result of arithmetic computations on your screen. It can also be utilized do display other Python data types.
  • Just like natural, human languages have grammar rules that define the structure of the language, programming languages have syntax rules. If you have incorrect syntax in your Python source code, the interpreter will halt execution at the source of the error and raise a SyntaxError.
  • We can make use of comments in our code to document the purpose of certain portions of the code.

We previously learned how to use Python as a calculator to perform operations on the integer and float numeric data types. One data type differs from another in its features and/or the operations that can be performed on data of that data type. For example, integers are whole numbers that you can perform arithmetical computations on. You can also perform arithmetical computations on floats, but they are numbers that contain a decimal point.

Strings are another one of Python's basic data types. A string is comprised of zero or more characters enclosed (delimited) in single '' or double "" quotation marks. There is no restriction on which characters, or the combination of characters that can be used to form a string.

Some examples of strings are:

  • "A"
  • 'Hello world'
  • "12345"
  • 'The company's profits increased by $45,000.'
  • "!@#$%^&*()%"
  • ''

Sometimes you'll want to include single and/or double quotes within a string. Remember that the Python interpreter determines if data is a string by looking for enclosing single or double quotes. Therefore, including single (double) quote(s) in a string that is delimited by single (double) quotes will result in a SyntaxError:


This is because the interpreter considers anything in between two quotation marks as a string, so it throws an error when you try including single quotes within a string that is delimited by single quotes. In the image above, you can see that 'This is a string containing ' is a light green color, indicating that it is a string. The interpreter mistakenly interpreted this smaller portion of the whole string we intended to create as the full string. The same thing would happen if we tried including double quotes within a string delimited by double quotes. So how can we get around this? There are a few options.

  • For a string that will only contain single or double quotes, just enclose the string in the other type of quotation marks. For example,
    • If you want a string to only include single quotes, enclose the string in double quotes:
      • "This is a string that contains 'single quotes' and is enclosed in double quotes."
    • If you want a string to only include double quotes, enclose the string in single quotes:
      • 'This is a string that contains "double quotes" and is enclosed in single quotes.'
  • You can escape quotes within a string by using the backslash \ character. The backslash character can be used with certain characters to inform the interpreter to ignore, or escape, the usual interpretation of that character.
    • If you want to include single (double) quotes in a string delimited by single (double) quotes, insert a backslash character right before the single (double) quote(s) that are within that string:

In addition, the backslash can be used on its own, or with other characters within a string for various purposes:


Finally, if you want to create a multiline string without having to use the escape sequence, you can enclose a string in triple single or double quotes. The benefit of using triple quotes is that you can include both single and double quotes within the string without having to escape them.

Coding Challenge

In a previous lesson, we utilized Python's built-in print() function to display the output of various math computations.

We can also use this function to print strings - just put the string (with quotes) within the parentheses of the print() function.

For this challenge, print the following strings on the screen, in the order presented below:

  • Hello and welcome to data expert!
  • The correct "term" is data expert
  • If you're going to give it a try, give it your all
fields.correctAnswer:
print('Hello and welcome to data expert!')
print('The correct "term" is data expert')
print('If you\'re going to give it a try, give it your all')

fields.defaultCode:
x = 30
y = 20
nyc = 'New York City is known as the "Big Apple"'
fl = 'Florida is known as the "Sunshine State"'
fields.htmlBody:
Data science is the most interesting and intellectually stimulating profession - True

There is no better place to learn data science than Data Expert - True

Data analyst is a good job - False, it is the best job.

The answers to the questions above, True or False, are known in computer programming as the boolean data types. Booleans can only be one of two values, True or False, and when using them in Python, you must always capitalize the first letter (T and F).

You will be working with booleans quite often, so it is in your best interest to familiarize yourself with how they work. Booleans are most commonly used in Python to compare two or more values, and we can do this by utilizing Python's comparison operators:

Operator Meaning
< strictly less than
<= less than or equal to
> strictly greater than
>= greater than or equal to
== equal
!= not equal
is object identity
is not negated object identity

The comparison operators can be used to compare any type of data - integers, floats, strings, and even booleans themselves.

Some things to note about comparing two or more strings:

  • If the strings are exactly the same, which includes capitalization, then Python will return True when you check for their equality.
  • Although you probably will not be comparing strings in this way often, when using the greater than or less than comparison operators with strings:
    • all lower case letters are considered "less than" uppercase ones
    • when comparing two letters of the same case, the one that comes first in the alphabet is "less than" any letters that come after it

We can also use the in keyword to check whether a certain string is contained in another string. Please note that capitalization matters.

                 x = 5
print('llo' in 'hello world')
print('expert' in 'DataExpert')
print('Expert' in 'DataExpert')
# Output 
# True
# False 
# True

For all of the comparisons above, we could have assigned the comparison expression to a variable. The value of that variable would be the boolean result of the expression, and therefore its data type would be boolean:

                    greater_than = 5 > 6 # The value of this variable becomes True 
study = 'in' in 'studying' # The value of this variable becomes False 
print(greater_than)
print(study)
# Output
# False
# True

We also frequently use booleans to filter data sets based on certain criteria. We will learn more about this use case later on.

Coding Challenge

We have created a few variables for you in the text editor to the right. Compare these variables as follows:

  • assign the comparison x not equal to y to the variable equal
  • assign the comparison x * y greater than 200 to the variable product
  • assign the comparison nyc equal to fl to the variable state
  • check whether the last element of nyc is equal to the last element of fl and assign it to the variable last (Hint: String Indexing & Slicing)
  • check whether the 13th - 31st (inclusive) elements of nyc are in fl and assign that to the variable isin
